Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is one of the few examples of Soulslike element integration done well - and, in general, manages a great blend of atmosphere and gameplay.

The skill/experience system works quite well and doesn't become too grind-heavy, even with the occasional death (it really helps that you can never lose gained skill points, only the progress to the next one). Combat flow works fine with just a few exceptions; plus, there's a difficulty selection! (The latter needs to be pointed out particularly in the Soulslike genre, after all most devs in there seem to not know how those work. So, if the game looks too intimidating, don't fret, you can set it to easy - and, at least in my experience, even hard [Jedi Master] isn't that bad in comparison to your usual Souls suspects.)
On the other hand, adding metroidvania elements on top of that wasn't exactly a good choice, backtracking becomes very tedious very quickly - while mostly avoidable unless you're gunning for full completion, an improved fast travel system (more landing points, or better interconnected areas) could've avoided that issue entirely.

The story and world building is, of course, very reference heavy (it's set in a well established universe after all), but it also fits well into established lore. (This isn't The Force Unleashed, where a ridiculous powerhouse had to be somehow shoehorned into the timeline without the latter falling completely apart. From that PoV, maybe it's a good thing that we're mostly past the era of PS2/PS3 action games.) And not only does the game impress with its graphical and audio design (which is, to be fair, to be expected from a AAA game because that's where most of the budget lands), but there's also lots of smaller details that make things fit together - from random storm trooper banter to the occasional rat scurrying into a concealed pathway to indicate the way forward (see, ledge painters? that's how you do it).

Particularly as AAA games go, Fallen Order is extraordinary. (Even more so as the publisher is EA, though that is as to be expected not without its downsides: not only do you need its client in the background but you also have to fix a registry entry containing the wrong installation path in order to get the game to launch. Still, they've done much worse on other occasions.)

The "tutorial/introduction" section really does this game a disservice it doesn't do a good job of accurately portraying the exploration or enemy placement you'll be doing later on. A solid game, worth getting on sale, but it is lacking. This game borrows quite a bit from Souls, which is a good thing but, they should've borrowed more. Having multiple usable items (not just your healing stims) or even having non-lightsaber weapons would add a lot.   Additional force powers unlocked from the get-go would be nice. The parrying is too strong in this game and it can turn into "simon says" between parrying or dodging when they're glowing red with their huge startup.

The current difficulties are too easy, easy and then hard because it's easy to die. I would've preferred harder enemies, perhaps a punishment for missing a parry, but give us more iframes for our dodge, give us better control over character (aka less startup frames), give us 3 stims to start and give us a little more health. There's an area on the first planet you visit where you do fine on the hardest difficulty until meet this enemy that's a harder version of a previous enemy you fought (same attacks and everything). Only difference is- it's got a lot of health and kills you in one hit. Presumably you're supposed to come back and fight this "once you've leveled up" but the leveling isn't like Souls where you can level a few times to grow your health and defense. You're given points to buy skills in a tree. There is one skill to upgrade your health... one time. Presumably in the future, only a few hours in, you'll get additional skills added to the skill tree but it ends up meaning if you wanna try to beat this guy before then it's gonna be a real pain- one mistake you're done. This wouldn't be so bad if it didn't feel like the controls fought against you. And again this isn't exactly a hard boss it's just easy to die versus it. Maybe they could've hidden this hard enemy behind a locked area you can only access once you unlock a force power later on?

The platforming and puzzles are so-so. I know they're there to "mix it up" which is fine. The item boxes you find a real let-down the majority of the time they're cosmetics. They should've contained useful items instead but the problem, as stated earlier, is that the only usable item you've got are your stims. No grenades, blasters, maybe a "scent" item that you could throw to distract creatures, a temporary stealth item, equippable armor, etc. nothing like this at all! 

A lot of effort was put into world-building with scanning environmental objects and creatures which frankly that time should have been spent adding more depth to the gameplay. It's nice to have but if I had to choose I'd rather have more items than be given a paragraph to read on why some pottery is relevant to the history of the place I'm in. Souls also did this better- they showed didn't tell a lot of the time giving the world a real mystery. Again it's fine if they keep in all this scanning crap but it feels like busy-work and it's not worth having at the detriment of more gameplay.

There is a lot to like and you do have to actually put some thought into the combat encounters which is a welcome change from many AAA games we see today (Callisto Protocol comes to mind where the combat is borderline mindless). I like the cramped, non-linear level design that helps make enemy combat encounters feel like you have to face them. Parts of the environments are destructible and you can cut creatures in half (a shame you can't slice stormtroopers in half but I get why). The world-building is well done; the story has been more engaging than even some of the films/tv shows that have come out in the past few years.

Worth grabbing on sale but a real wasted opportunity to be something much more gameplay-wise. For a Star Wars game one of the best but still loses out to Dark Forces (and some would argue the Battlefront series but I haven't played much of that).

The best thing about  this game is the VERY innovative, luck-based combat system. See, the developers realized that the slow, cowardly and predictable enemies in this game were still too easy to beat. At first they tried designing Cal Kestis to be a goofy klutz who constantly trips over his own feet, then they gave him bizarrely slow attacks, as if he were fighting underwater. All of this helped, but the enemies were still just pitifully easy to dispatch, so slow and clumsy that they often just threw themselves off ledges without even having to fight them. THAT'S when the ultimate innovation came. One of the developers asked "What if we only give it the APPEARANCE of being a slow-paced Team Ninja clone with clunkier controls, but we introduce a sort-of behind the scenes dice-roll mechanic EVERY SINGLE TIME the player pushes a button? Just think, a roughly 1 in 4 chance of the character jumping, blocking and attacking with each button push. Being a powerful young apprentice fighting storm troopers is boring, but the THRILL of barely being able to use your arms and legs is what will keep our customers coming back the years, nay months, during which we will continue to pretend to offer customers support!"

And so it was, with this BRILLIANT innovation, that Jedi: Fallen Order became the greatest Star Wars action game of all time, solidifying EA's reputation as the greatest game developer of all time.

This game is very aesthetically interesting. The story is serviceable and the environments are pretty and the platforming is okay. It has Disney-era hallmarks that harm the experience on a narrative and aesthetic level, but it doesn't feel contemptuous of the George Lucas era in the way most Disney products do, and even occasionally gives the impression that someone working on the game was, in fact, a Star Wars fan. 

The main reason why I'm taking the time to leave a negative review is, largely, due to a persistent issue I've noticed in many modern games, that I severely dislike and causes constant problems to anyone who actually likes video games to be video games, as opposed to interactive movies. It's something I call "animation-based movement", as opposed to "movement-based animation." What do I mean by that? I mean that in most games, or at least older games, the way you interacted with the world was that you would press a button to move, and that button would make your character move. This was predictable and constant; the moment you pressed, the character would begin accelerating in the direction you pressed, and the only thing that would alter your movement was any previous momentum you had, or the surface you were moving on. It was up to the animation system to try and play an animation that fit with what you were doing. Hence, movement-based animation.

In many modern, "cinematic", usually third person games, this is flipped on its head. Pressing the movement button does NOT make you move; instead, it plays a contextual animation, which has movement associated with it. So, say I'm playing an old platformer. My character is facing to the right, and I press "forward". I immediately move forward at a constant acceleration, and the character probably awkwardly flips facing and begins doing a running animation. However, in this game, my character will instead begin running right, do a shuffle to the left, hook around, and then begin moving forward. Because pressing the movement button doesn't make me move, not directly, it instead makes me play the contextual animation associated with moving forward from a right-facing position.

This makes everything feel sluggish and unresponsive, and most of all, inconsistent. This inconsistency underpins the gameplay of the entire game, and makes it unrewarding and uninteresting to try and master the platforming or combat system. Every button press has a significant delay, every combat suffers from significant action stacking, and every attempt to dodge or parry suffers from inconsistency due to the fact that the game is trying to figure out how to play its animations instead of actually following your commands.

This seems to be, to at least some degree, intended behavior. The devs appear to want you to play in a sort of detached state where you spend a good portion of time just waiting around for animations to be done, and enemies are programmed in such a way that if you have a relatively good reaction time, you will be punished, because your actions will lead to you getting stuck in animations. Instead, the intended combat is to stand in place and wait for enemies to begin doing a little dance, at which point you will slowly respond by either pressing the block button or the dodge button, which will automatically solve the problem and then you hit the attack button once, and wait around for this to repeat. Touching the movement controls is more often than not a mistake, because of action stacking and animation delays. This makes for an understandable system which one can master over time in order to achieve some sort of proficiency that will let you consistently take down enemies. It's also extremely fucking boring and unrewarding, and in the end, unimmersive.

And it's all rather ironic, since the entire purpose of an animation-based movement system is supposed to be to cut out any animation jank and ensure the player stays immersed by making everything look choreographed. But the thing is, if I'm just looking at choreography, I'm not fucking involved in the game, now am I? It's hard to be immersed in a video game that is actively fighting me at the controls layer.

Combine this with the fact that, despite using a lightsaber, enemies are basically just damage sponges you have to decapitate anywhere from 5 to 20 times in order to actually kill, and this leaves you with a profoundly unsatisfying combat system. And honestly, I can only even blame the devs halfway on this, because this has somehow become an industry standard. It's bewildering.

I played for 3 hours and I feel like I had only 10 minutes of proper combat in total (random critters that pop out the ground are not what I count towards proper combat, they're just purely there to be annoying), which is the most fun part of this game. [b]The visuals are stunning, audio is nice too... but it all just feels... empty? Soulless?[/b] I didn't feel much in particular during those 3 hours. It kinda says a lot that the most excitement I felt was when I realised I can customize my lightsaber and outfit, cause it reminded my of Force Unleashed.

The puzzles felt crammed in half the time, [b]the maps felt claustrophobic [/b](especially dark areas you have to light up with your lightsaber that turns off everytime you have to do a jump, leaving you in darkness, that instead of building tension just makes you wanna move on to the next area as soon as possible) [b]despite being open-world in a sense[/b] and felt like what I can only describe is 'video-gamey' if that makes sense (the constant slopes to slide down into new areas got boring and on the nose real quick), and the pacing of exploring an area just felt a bit slow. The constant parkour gets annoying quickly as well, which would maybe be less of a nuisance if the movement was quicker and more fluid, but it just feels cumbersome sometimes. [b]Having to backtrack to the ship feels insulting sometimes.[/b]

The lightsaber combat feels clunkier than it should sometimes and robs you of the satisfaction of just slicing through stuff, instead making it feel like normal melee weapon with a slightly sharper edge than usual. Oh, and [b]in the 3 hours I've played, the number of times I have been pushed off the edge of the map by a random creature sprinting into me from outside of my field of view is frankly comical[/b] (in a way that doesn't feel like a skill issue on my part, but instead unsatisfying game design).

The best thing about  this game is the VERY innovative, luck-based combat system. See, the developers realized that the slow, cowardly and predictable enemies in this game were still too easy to beat. At first they tried designing Cal Kestis to be a goofy klutz who constantly trips over his own feet, then they gave him bizarrely slow attacks, as if he were fighting underwater. All of this helped, but the enemies were still just pitifully easy to dispatch, so slow and clumsy that they often just threw themselves off ledges without even having to fight them. THAT'S when the ultimate innovation came. One of the developers asked "What if we only give it the APPEARANCE of being a slow-paced Team Ninja clone with clunkier controls, but we introduce a sort-of behind the scenes dice-roll mechanic EVERY SINGLE TIME the player pushes a button? Just think, a roughly 1 in 4 chance of the character jumping, blocking and attacking with each button push. Being a powerful young apprentice fighting storm troopers is boring, but the THRILL of barely being able to use your arms and legs is what will keep our customers coming back the years, nay months, during which we will continue to pretend to offer customers support!"

And so it was, with this BRILLIANT innovation, that Jedi: Fallen Order became the greatest Star Wars action game of all time, solidifying EA's reputation as the greatest game developer of all time.
